content:
Late this morning a group of Cooper Union students began a sit-in inside university president Jamshed Bharucha’s office, their numbers quickly swelling to over 60 by some reports as more students and, according to Hyperallergic, at least three faculty members who have joined them to sign a vote of no confidence in Bharucha, who many see as the man responsible for the school’s recent decision to start charging tuition for the first time in its 154-year history.

Students also unfurled black banners form the school’s Cooper Union Foundation Building as a symbol of mourning for the mission of the institution’s founder, Peter Cooper, who wanted to create a school that was “open and free to all.” According to Free Cooper Union, a student group involved in the occupation that has been tweeting and livestreaming the sit-in, about half of the university’s art students have signed the no-confidence vote document — the school, which offers courses in art, engineering, and architecture, has just under 1,000 students in total.

Stay tuned for updates as the story develops.

— Benjamin Sutton

(Photos via @FreeCooperUnion/Twitter.)
